TextEquiv.Unicode: folkes and not in mariage. For mar
riage of it selfe is good, but many use
not well the thing that is good, and
therefore they feele the smart of their
soule abuse worthily. For who kno
weth not that the faulte of drunken
nesse is not to bee referred to wine
which is the good and holesome crea
ture of God, but to the excessive bib
bing and ever great greedinesse of ma
which abuseth Gods good creature?
That which commeth out of the heart
of man (saith the Lorde in the Gospel)
and not that which goeth in by the
mouth, defileth the man. Hereunto
belongth that saying of Paul the A
postle of Christ, where he attributeth
sanctification to wedlocke: for the bed
(saith he) is undefiled: and in an other
place he testifieth that the unbeleeving
husband is sanctified by the beleeving
wife: hee affirmeth also that children
borne in wedlocke are holy or cleane.
Moreover the same Paul maketh
Christ an example of love betwixt ma
and wife: and shadoweth ye mysteries
of Christ and the Church by the colour
of wedlocke: he figureth (I say) a hea
venly thing by an holy type taht God
doth allowe. Whereuppon in an other
place the same Apostle doth say: That
their doctrine is a verie doctrine of
devils which forbid men to marie.
And so consequently it followeth that
that is an heavely doctrine proceeding
from God, which permitteth mariage
freely to all men, and doth commende
and reverence it.
The excellencie and dignitie of ma
trimonie being thus understoode, let
us now seeke out and looke on the cau
ses, for which God hath ordeyned ma
riage for men to imbrace. god accor
ding to his natural goodnesse directeth
all his ordinaunces to the great good
and aboundant commoditie or mortall

folkes and not in mariage. For mar riage of it selfe is good, but many use not well the thing that is good, and therefore they feele the smart of their soule abuse worthily. For who kno weth not that the faulte of drunken nesse is not to bee referred to wine which is the good and holesome crea ture of God, but to the excessive bib bing and ever great greedinesse of ma which abuseth Gods good creature? That which commeth out of the heart of man (saith the Lorde in the Gospel) and not that which goeth in by the mouth, defileth the man. Hereunto belongth that saying of Paul the A postle of Christ, where he attributeth sanctification to wedlocke: for the bed (saith he) is undefiled: and in an other place he testifieth that the unbeleeving husband is sanctified by the beleeving wife: hee affirmeth also that children borne in wedlocke are holy or cleane. Moreover the same Paul maketh Christ an example of love betwixt ma and wife: and shadoweth ye mysteries of Christ and the Church by the colour of wedlocke: he figureth (I say) a hea venly thing by an holy type taht God doth allowe. Whereuppon in an other place the same Apostle doth say: That their doctrine is a verie doctrine of devils which forbid men to marie. And so consequently it followeth that that is an heavely doctrine proceeding from God, which permitteth mariage freely to all men, and doth commende and reverence it. The excellencie and dignitie of ma trimonie being thus understoode, let us now seeke out and looke on the cau ses, for which God hath ordeyned ma riage for men to imbrace. god accor ding to his natural goodnesse directeth all his ordinaunces to the great good and aboundant commoditie or mortall
men: and therefore it followeth that
hee ordeyned matrimonie for the pre
servation of mankind to the ende that
mans life might be pleasaunt, sweets
and throughly furnished with joyes
sufficient. But al these causes may bee
reduced into ye number of three. First
God himselfe doth say: It is not good
for man to be alone, let us make him
an helpe therefore to bee before him,
or to dwell with him. So then the first
cause why wedlocke was instituted,
is mans commoditie, that thereby the
life of man might bee the pleasaunter
and more comodious. For Adam see
med not to live halfe happilie nor
sweetely enough, unlesse he had a wife
to joyne himsefe unto: which wife is
not in the Scriptures called an impe
diment or necessarie evill, as certaine
Poets and beastly men, who hated
women, have foolishly langled, but she
is the helpe or arme of the man. An
tipater an heathen writer In Sermone
de Nuptys, doeth wonderfully agree
with this saying of the scripture, and
expresseth plainly what kinde of helpe
and what manner of arme the wife is
to her husband. Whosoever, sayth he
hath not had triall of wyfe and chil
dren, hee is utterly ignoraunt of true
mutuall goodwill. Love in wedlocke
is mutually shewed, when man and
wife doe not comunicate wealth, chil
dren, and heartes also, as friendes are
wont to doe, but have their bodies in
comon also, which friends cannot do.
And therefore Euripides laying aside
the deadly hate that he bare to wome,
writ these verses in commendation of
marriage.
The wife that gads not gigglot wife
with everie flirting gill,
Bul honestly doth keepe at home,
not set to gossip still.

men: and therefore it followeth that hee ordeyned matrimonie for the pre servation of mankind to the ende that mans life might be pleasaunt, sweets and throughly furnished with joyes sufficient. But al these causes may bee reduced into ye number of three. First God himselfe doth say: It is not good for man to be alone, let us make him an helpe therefore to bee before him, or to dwell with him. So then the first cause why wedlocke was instituted, is mans commoditie, that thereby the life of man might bee the pleasaunter and more comodious. For Adam see med not to live halfe happilie nor sweetely enough, unlesse he had a wife to joyne himsefe unto: which wife is not in the Scriptures called an impe diment or necessarie evill, as certaine Poets and beastly men, who hated women, have foolishly langled, but she is the helpe or arme of the man. An tipater an heathen writer In Sermone de Nuptys, doeth wonderfully agree with this saying of the scripture, and expresseth plainly what kinde of helpe and what manner of arme the wife is to her husband. Whosoever, sayth he hath not had triall of wyfe and chil dren, hee is utterly ignoraunt of true mutuall goodwill. Love in wedlocke is mutually shewed, when man and wife doe not comunicate wealth, chil dren, and heartes also, as friendes are wont to doe, but have their bodies in comon also, which friends cannot do. And therefore Euripides laying aside the deadly hate that he bare to wome, writ these verses in commendation of marriage. The wife that gads not gigglot wife with everie flirting gill, Bul honestly doth keepe at home, not set to gossip still.
